Notice that finding a solution to f(x)=x is the same as finding the root of an equation g(x)=f(x)-x.
How can you use the tangent line y=5x-7 to give you information about <math>\displaystyle{}f(x_0)</math> and <math>\displaystyle{}f'(x_0)</math>?
question: 1 (g)
sols_html:
We want to find a solution to

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}f(x)=x\end{aligned}\]

and so we begin by defining a function

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}g(x)=f(x)-x\end{aligned}\]

so that we can think instead of finding roots to g(x). Recall that the Newton-Raphson Method for finding roots to a function g(x) gives a future approximation (\(x_{n+1}\)) based on a current approximation (\(x_n\)) as

\[\begin{aligned} x_{n+1}=x_n-\frac{g(x_n)}{g'(x_n)}.\end{aligned}\]

Therefore, in our case

\[\begin{aligned} x_1=x_0-\frac{g(x_0)}{g'(x_0)}=3-\frac{g(3)}{g'(3)}\end{aligned}\]

since \(x_0=3\). The task now is to find what g(3) and g’(3) are. Since g(x)=f(x)-x then

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}g'(x)=f'(x)-1\end{aligned}\]

so we really only need to determine f(3) and f’(3). To do this we can use the tangent line which is also the linear approximation to f(x). Therefore we have that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}f(x)\approx{}5x-7=5x-15+8=8+5(x-3)=f(3)+f'(3)(x-3).\end{aligned}\]

Therefore, we have that f(3)=8 and f’(3)=5. Similarly, we then have that,

\[\begin{aligned} g(3)=f(3)-3=8-3&=5\\ g'(3)=f'(3)-1=5-1&=4\end{aligned}\]

and so we get that,

\[\begin{aligned} x_1=3-\frac{g(3)}{g'(3)}=3-\frac{5}{4}=\frac{7}{4}.\end{aligned}\]

Therefore the next approximation to the solution is \(x_1=7/4\).
